bibl.title: Letter from T.D. Nettles to P.F. Murphy, November 13, 1922

div1.p: Shipping manager Nettles informs medical officer Murphy about the route taken by a ship where a possible yellow fever death occurred. He describes quarantine and treatment of the ship at Mobile, Ala.

div1.head: Letter from T.D. Nettles to P.F. Murphy, November 13, 1922
div1.opener:
COPY
UNITED FRUIT COMPANY
Mobile, Alabama.
November 13, 1922.
Dr. P. F. Murphy
Port Medical Officer
New Orleans, La.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
I am in receipt of your favor of the 11th instant, asking infor-
mation concerning the Schooner “William E. Burnham” which arrived in Mobile
in September with a supposed case of yellow fever. Upon investigation I
find that this vessel stopped at Sierra Leone, West Coast of Africa, and
proceeded to Paramaribo, Dutch Guiana, and loaded a cargo of Ore for Mobile
and arrived in the city on September 20, 1922.

As the owners state that the crew did not go ashore at the former
port, it is quite evident that the disease was contracted at Paramaribo. On
arrival of the vessel at Fort Morgan, the corpse was taken ashore and buried.
The ship was fumigated and the crew detained for six days and then allowed
to proceed to Mobile to discharge her cargo. There is a reasonable doubt
as to whether the man really had yellow fever from the fact that the vessel
had made a long trip and none of the other members of the crew were affected.

This ship sailed on October 7 for Moss Point to load lumber for
Santiago.

As a matter of information, in case you have occasion to confer
with other parties on ships arriving from an infected port or with sickness
aboard, will advise when a ship arrives under such circumstances, it does
not mean that she proceeds to the city proper but is held at Quarantine
Station, which is at Fort Morgan, about thirty-five miles away.
Trusting the above will give you all the desired information,
